dialogue: IMPACT IN EIGHT SECONDS!
WE CAN'T BREAK FREE!
We get Ivan into the Comets PATH--
Billy, that's BRILLIANT!
It's passing over earth as we speak!  Trajectory coordinates are 009843.
Wait a second...  What time is it?
He's on us!!
Speed?
We've got him locked!
Zordon...  he's gone.
What?!
Rangers...  I'm afraid you're too late.
How can we reach Phaedos?
Ay, yi, yi, yi.  The legend speaks of a Master Warrior who lives on the planet Phaedos... This is the only person who knows the secrets of the power.
If we don't try, Zordon won't survive!
It's far too dangerous.  Zordon would never allow it.
... Perhaps there is a way... I have heard tales of another power.
Alpha.  Is there any way we can defeat this  monster?  Any way at all?
Stylin'!
Aisha, you are the Bear, stalwart and bold.
Now tell me... what do you see?
Wow.  Sand.
It will not harm you.
Yeah, right.
In the language of the Nathadians, "Nin" stands for "man", "jetti" stands for "animal".  Ninjetti  - man and animal, together as one.  Now, put your hands inside the flame.
Ah... sure.
He wants to know if you'd like a cube of sugar in your tea.
The only way to obtain the power is to achieve the highest state of being...
So how can we get to it?
They're called squirbs.
Is this... food!
OUR SEMI-CONDUCTORS ARE DOWN!
SYSTEM MALFUNCTION!
I've got it!  We use the mirrors to reflect the light back into itself!!
Release the power with the power.
There should be a way to open it.
We've come all this way for a rock wall?!
I've never been this sore in my life.
I can hardly walk...
Outside of his time warp he's aging at a vastly acellerated rate!
... What's happening to him?'
I'll be at the Observatory Sunday.
I heard that!
Everybody hold on tight.  We're gonna send this sucker into OBLIVION!
1600 m.p.h.  and increasing!
What does that mean?!
Release the power WITH the power.
Thank you, Dulcea.  For everything.
That's pretty bad.
Activating Power Beam!
Let's teach these vermin a few manners.
WHITE TIGER!
SABER TOOTH TIGER!
... Let's take a look over there.
Anybody see anything?
Don't lose hope yet, Alpha!
Ay, yi, yi!  The Rangers are going to be CRUSHED!
... I just pray we're not too late.
By bouncing ultra-high frequencies off one of the network satellites, I can send a long-range pulsar signal to within TWO FEET of the Rangers coordinates.
... We must try to communicate with them.
I told them it was too dangerous, but they wouldn't listen.
... Alpha, I am deeply concerned about the Rangers...
Hey, NOBODY enters the Command Center without a power coin!
Alpha, my sensors tell me the Rangers were too late!  Ivan is on his way here!
Use extreme caution, Rangers. You are dealing with an evil here that is beyond ALL comprehension.
To assist you I have retro-fitted your helmets with new Opti-Scan devices.
The chamber has been accidently UNCOVERED!  You must return it to the depths. or  anyone should open it and Ivan is released!
In a place that came to be known as Angel Grove.
About twenty seconds in your time.
What's a Triac?
It is said that once you've reached the power... you have only ten triacs to release it.
Close.  Billy, you are the Wolf, cunning and swift.
I see... a fox

In another time, another dimension.  It was brought here long ago by the "Nathadians", a people who are now all but extinct. They built an impenetrable stone Monolith to store the power and keep it from their enemies.  For thousands of years, beings from all over the Universe have tried to obtain it... ALL have perished.
Where did it originate?
It is said that to those who possess the Power... all things are possible.
This guy is messing with the wrong teenagers!
All systems go!
NINJA WOLF ZORD!
NINJA CRANE ZORD!
WE'VE GOT TEN TRIACS BEFORE WE'RE TOAST!!
Of course!  The power is of another world.  Another dimension.
I am the crane, agile and sublime!
I am the wolf, cunning and swift!
I think so.
You okay?
TRICERATOPS!
PTERODACTYL!
THERE'S THE COMET!
009843... 42... 41!  WE'RE IN ALIGNMENT!
GIVE IT EVERYTHING WE'VE GOT!
THREE DEGREES OFF THE COMETS TRAJECTORY!
Ryan's Comet!!
Two thirty three a.m.
OUR MORPHERS ARE ON LINE!
NEW POWER COINS!!
Release the power with the power.
... Nothing.
We can take these guys!
That's the only way to the Monolith...
WE'RE OUTTA HERE!
FOUR SECONDS TO IMPACT!
WE HAVE TO GET OUT OF HERE!!
IMPACT IN FIFTEEN SECONDS!
LET'S FLY!
I'm in!
Ultra Ninja Megazord complete!
Let's go after him!!
Listen, we appreciate your hospitality, but we really don't have much time.
... Not bad.
BULK!!
SKULL!!
A real shame.
There goes the neighborhood.
If we told you -- we'd have to kill you.
Uh... that's classified, top secret, confidential, undercover information.
There's enough for everybody!
Here you go!  No pushing!
A stellar idea, Skull.
Bulk... why don't we give Mr. Peep here a chance to think it over?
We could smell it's breath.
The earth was hurtling toward us at seven hundred miles per hour, and we knew at that moment that we were facing death straight in the eye.
Be the swallow.  Be the swallow...
Be the eagle.  Be the eagle.
Ditto for the Swooping Swallow.
The Stealth Eagle is about to fly.
The legend goes that you release the power with the power.
And how do we release the power?
Tommy, you are the Falcon, Winged Lord of the Sky.
... A falcon?
Look closer.
It's... an eagle?
By learning the ancient art of Ninjetti.  It is the Genesis of what you on earth have come to know as the Ninja.  It is the perfect union of mind, body and spirit.
And how do we do that?
SECOND COUSIN, THREE TIMES REMOVED.  NOW  GET OFF ME!
BUT I'M YOUR COUSIN!
GET OFF ME!
Wait for me!
I'm outta here.
Did I say anything?
Just shut your gap!
How about Major Moron?
As soon as we've taken over the world I'm gonna change my name to Sir Mordant.  Or how about MAJOR Mordant?!
What kind of landing was that?! These clowns are a menace to the sky
Hey, boss!
Couldn''t stand them -- low-class all the way.  And did you catch a whiff of their BREATH?!  It's like having a conversation with a couple of ONIONS!  Not to mention...
We never liked the cheesedongs in the first place.
GO IVAN!!
THE BOYS ARE BACK IN TOWN!!!
You forgot to say 'Simon says."
What!
Quack like a'duck!
Simon says...
Ah, the old and doddering.  I'm going to SCOURGE their puny minds, reducing them to ZOMBIE'S. And then I'll put them to work rebuilding my empire.
But boss, what about their parents?

Yes, well, I suppose you'd know a little something about that.  Not to worry.  I'll ever so gently lure them in and mold them into an army of devils!  And what better way to entice them ... than with a little Ivan's Ooze?!
No offense, boss, but they might find you a little disgusting.
You want me to place a few calls?
Taking over the world is one thing.  It's finding good help to run it for you that's the killer.

Feast your eyes upon the exoskeleton of the barbaric HORNITOR!  KEEP DIGGING.  THE DREADFUL SCORPITRON SHOULD BE CLOSE BY.  ONCE I HAVE MY ECTO-MORPHICON MACHINES UP AND RUNNING, I SHALL ANNIHILATE ANGEL GROVE... AND THEN... THE WORLD
What is THAT!
Dulcea!  That miserable, manipulating loathsome she-devil of a WITCH!!
How'd you know?
Did these sticks make a whistling sound?
Well... we were about to finish them off... when this huge monster came out of nowhere!
What do you mean "basically"?
Basically.
So they've been destroyed?
That's right.  And then we threw one of them off a mountain and another one into a raqing river!
You know boss, I'd really like to help out but I've got this gastronomic condition which rules out all space trave--
Mordant, go with them and report back to me!
We couldn't have done it better ourselves.
That was a CHEAP shot!
GO POWER RANGERS!
I hope those Rangers put that lousy lowlife out of his misery!
From now on it's E-V-I-L, NO exceptions!
Isn't this just TYPICAL!  We finally do somebody a good turn and just look what happens!
How dare you?!  Nobody shuts up Rita but me!
Rrgh mmffpprr brghuh!!
Well, if I did I certainly wouldn't say it to you!
Don't you ever have anything nice to say?!
NINJA FALCON ZORD!
NINJA APE ZORD!
LET'S DO IT!?
THREE SECONDS!!
And I am the Falcon, Winged Lord of the Sky!
I am the mighty ape!
Strength in numbers!!
Six become one... the combined forces of the Ninjetti.
What's going on?!
How the heck?!...
Activating Power Scope!
Anybody see them?

I have given a great deal of thought to that possibility, and I am prepared to face it.  If it should come to war, and I presume that is what you are alluding to, I would rather have war with the Emperor than my own people.

Your Majesty knows my affection for him is deep and genuine, and goes far beyond my official role as Ambassador.  But I would be remiss in my feelings for you, and in my responsibility to the Emperor, if I did not say that it is entirely possible that the Emperor will view your refutation of the terms of the Treaty of Tilsit, as the first step in the exchange of a French alliance for an English one -- with all the dangers that might entail.

My dear Caulaincourt, you have no idea of how compromised my own position has become since Tilsit.  I am blamed by the army for the military disaster at Austerlitz and Friedland, by the nobility for ruining their trade with England, by the merchants who must accept French foods at unprofitable prices, and by the nation for allowing Napoleon to dictate Russian policy.

I am in no position to debate this with you, Your Majesty, but can you imagine what a blow it will be to the Emperor if you should now desert his cause?  It would mean nothing less than victory for England.

It's a fine thing to establish policies but, when they don't work, they must be reconsidered.  Granted that you have hurt England, but she is still on her feet.  And to seal off her trade with Europe, what has it cost you?  You have had to rule with an iron hand.  You have turned friends into enemies.  And even at that, the result has only been partly effective.  You have never been able to stop the extensive cheating, smuggling and corruption -- even of your own officials.  But I should think the situation in Spain, alone, would give your policy a minus balance.  You have had to commit a quarter of a million of your best troops against the guerrillas, with no victory in sight. And you have given England a dangerous foothold on the Continent, for her armies.

I can appreciate what Your Majesty is saying but the Emperor has staked everything on this policy.  He has no other way to attack England, and no one knows more than Your Majesty how his overtures for peace have been rejected.

My dear Caulaincourt, agreements can endure only when they allow both sides to live.  Napoleon may believe it is necessary to injure England but, before that, he must realize it is necessary for him to allow his friends to live.  He cannot expect me to tell my nobles they must ruin themselves so that he can bring England to her knees -- and I'm afraid that is what it has come to.

But, Your Majesty, the very substance of the Tilsit treaty was that you should join the Continental Blockade, boycott English goods, suspend all commercial dealings with her, and be France's ally.  Nothing more is being asked than to comply with the treaty.

It is a thing entirely unknown in diplomacy, that one government should assume a right to dictate to another, who is upon terms of equality, the conditions on which she should conduct her commerce; and, assuming such a right, second it by threatening language, in case of non-compliance.
I am at your disposal, Your Majesty.
General Kutusov, I would like to call a meeting of my cabinet tomorrow morning and have you present this idea to them.  I think it has merit and is worthy of consideration.

If he withdraws his army in good order, it will be a serious political defeat.  But, if he should be caught on the move, with his army, in the full grip of winter, then it will be a catastrophe.  If Your Majesty can prolong his hopes for a treaty by silence, be deceit, by any means, for another month, thus postponing his departure, then the graves of his army are already dug in the soil of Russia.

I, personally, am convinced that he will withdraw his army from Moscow, and attempt to establish himself in Poland for the winter.  In the end, he will not allow himself to be cut off from Paris.  But I believe that if he is offered any encouragement, by Your Majesty, he will postpone this decision as long as possible. He is a gambler and he will trust to his luck.
What do you think Napoleon will do?

If I can presume to go into the Emperor's mind, I believe that he has based his entire campaign strategy on obtaining a peace treaty after the fall of Moscow.  When Vienna fell, there was a peace treaty.  When Berlin fell, another treaty.  That has always been the rules of the game.  But what is he to do now if no treaty is forth- coming?  He knows that beyond Moscow, there is nothing, and that, if he withdraws, there remains only a fall into emptiness.
Proceed.

Perhaps it would be even more serious than that, Your Majesty. His European confederation is held together by some very slender threads.  Your Majesty knows even better than I that Austria and Prussia are very doubtful allies, and the Emperor has reason enough to fear that they will turn on him, at the first sign of weakness.
I must confess he would look a bit silly, fighting his way to Moscow and turning right around again.

Your Majesty has grasped the outlines of his problem in much less time than it took me.  This is a crucial point -- and it is a political one, which Your Majesty will be in a far better position to answer than I.  Can Napoleon afford to abandon Moscow without signing even the preliminaries of a peace treaty with you?
Well, one thing immediately comes to mind, if what you are saying is true -- he would merely withdraw his army from Moscow and return to Poland for the winter.
I have no doubt that he has, Your Majesty, but does he have any strong moves from which to choose?

Well, that is a very interesting idea, General Kutusov, but I can assure you that Napoleon is no beginner at this.  Whatever analysis you have done on this situation, I am sure that he has gone over the same ground.
The point is that I don't think Napoleon will sit in Moscow until the spring!  I don't think he can afford to.
Ah, yes -- proceed.
Forgive me, Your Majesty, I am about to make it.
I will accept your assurance, but I'm afraid I don't see your point.

You have my absolute assurance, Your Majesty, that Napoleon does not have the strength to attack St. Petersburg now -- his army is exhausted and ill-supplied, and he would be defeated if he attempted that.

Yes, General Kutusov, I daresay that this has been considered and discussed at great length.  Napoleon would simply spend the winter in Moscow and continue the campaign in the spring.  Another lesser possibility might be to march on St. Petersburg now, although there is some doubt that he has the strength to do this, until he refits his army.
Well, has Your Majesty considered what Napoleon's alternatives might be, if you simply chose to ignore his note?
For the sake of your argument, let us say that is correct.

The point I was trying to make is that I think it is reasonable to say that Your Majesty would not find himself under unbearable pressure, if he decided to make peace with the Emperor, at least at this time.
Rostopchin is a fanatic and he is capable of anything -- however, it doesn't affect what we are talking about.  Please go on.
I have heard that story but I do not believe it.
You know, General Kutusov, there is a very strong possibility that the fire was not started by Napoleon's troops but was organized under the orders of Rostopchin's secret police.

But, since the fire, a completely new spirit has been aroused in the nation.  The French have become an army of criminals, against whom Russia must be avenged, against whom she is now prepared to fight to the death.
Proceed.
I believe I am right in saying that, before the fire, the country had grown weary of the war, and there were few who were interested in continuing the battle.
General Kutusov, feel free to say whatever you like.
If I may, Your Majesty, I would like to offer a dissenting opinion.
I have decided to accept the principle of a negotiation; the terms are not established.
Your Majesty, I have been advised that you have received a letter from Napoleon, offering a peace treaty, and that you have decided to accept it.
Very well, General, what is it you wish to say?
I hope you will forgive me, Your Majesty, for requesting an audience at such a late hour, but I have traveled all the way from Moscow to see you, on a matter which cannot wait.
I know absolutely nothing of war -- and I am still totally dependent upon my generals.
What do you mean?
Ah, my dear Napoleon, sometimes I feel that I am not really an Emperor as you are.

Without a doubt, to estimate the enemy's strength on the battlefield. This is something that is only acquired by experience and instinct. At Jena, there were as many opinions about strength of the enemy as there were generals present.  Murat said there were 50,000, preparing to attack.  Berthier said there were no more than 25,000, about to withdraw. "Berthier sees only what is in the open," Murat said.  "But don't forget there is a second force hidden in the forest."  And so it would always go, each of them would judge things according to his own ability, character and state of mind, at the moment.
Fascinating!  Tell me, leaving aside the question of grand strategy, for the moment, what would you say is the single most difficult tactical skill to master?

You can always tell at a glance whether retreating infantry are being pursed by cavalry, because they hurry along and keep turning around and looking back.  When they are retreating before infantry, they merely trudge along, head down.
I shall tell you in the strictest confidence -- when I was a boy, I had a passion for rafts, and never had the opportunity to build one.
Whatever suggested the idea to you?
I'm glad you like it.
I think it's absolutely charming.
Ah -- you approve?
And, what a delightful idea!
And, what a great pleasure it is, indeed, to meet you, Alexander.

Look, let me be completely open with you, I have a carriage and an escort waiting for me, and I have a great deal of money outside of France. Unless we stand a very good chance of carrying this off, I am prepared to call it quits right now.
Our lives, the revolution, my career?
You realize what is at stake?
I'm not insulted.
I must be honest with you.  I first approached three generals more senior than yourself, and they all very prudently sent excuses.
Fair enough.
In every practical sense, yes, but, officially, of course, I would have to retain command.
Are you proposing to transfer command to me?
Would you be prepared to handle this for me?
The numbers are not particularly relevant.  You are not up against soldiers -- this is a mob, and they will run as soon as things become sufficiently unpleasant.
These are odds of 8 to 1.
Properly arranged, yes.
Is this enough to oppose 40,000 men?
You could have them here by daybreak.
Well, I believe there are at least 30 guns at Sablons.
Where are they?
There are none here.
Any cannon?
The 21st Dragoons, about two or three-hundred troopers.
Cavalry?
About 5,000 troops.
What forces do you have at your disposal?
I don't even know whether a defense is possible.
Are you serious?
To be perfectly honest, I haven't the vaguest idea.
What do you have in mind?
We expect an attack on the Convention tomorrow morning, at daybreak, and I have been placed in charge of its defense.
Things are quite serious, I should say.
I don't have to tell you of our latest difficulties.
No, thank you.
Thank you for coming.  Would you care for a drink?
I'm sorry, I was at the theater and I didn't receive your note until I returned to my hotel.
Ah, my dear friend, come in, come in.  Please sit down.
May I come to the map?
Please...
Yes, with all due respect, I do Citizen Barras.
Yes, Captain?  Have you anything you wish to say?
I did, sir.
Yes -- who spoke up?

What cowardice!  What treason! Joseph has ruined everything.  How could they all lose their heads. They knew I was coming up fast. Victory was just within grasp. Come, come, turn your troops around, General Belliard.
I don't know what has happened to Prince Joseph.
And where is Joseph?
I don't know, sire.
Who sent my wife and son out of Paris?
I believe it was arranged by Marshals Mortier and Marmont.  I must explain to you that we have had no orders all day.  Each marshal has been keeping his own position.
But who made this treaty?
I don't know the details of the treaty, sire, Marshal Mortier sent me word of its having been agreed to, and he said that I was to take the army and make for Fontainebleau.
A treaty?  Don't be ridiculous. What treaty is this?  Who made it? Who has been giving orders?

But, sire, Your Majesty would lay Paris open to being sacked.  The enemy is outside the gates with more than 120,000 men.  Besides this, I left the city under the terms of a treaty and I am forbidden to reenter Paris.
The Empress, your son and the whole court left two days ago for Rambouillet.  Marshals Mortier and Marmont are probably still in Paris, completing the arrangements.
But where are my wife and son? What's become of them?  Where is Marmont?  Where is Mortier?
Unhappily, it is true, sire.
Paris has surrendered?!  I don't believe it.
Paris is evacuated, sire.  The enemy is to enter at nine o'clock tomorrow morning.  The National Guard is on duty at the gates.
And who is defending Paris?
It is on this road, sire, following me.
And where is the army?
They are at the gates of Paris, sire.
Well, Belliard, what's this?  What are you doing here?  Where is the enemy?
I wanted to kiss her, but she didn't want to kiss me... She slipped away, the moment I wanted to take her in my arms.
No, sire... I was asleep.

She was sitting there... and it was as if I had last seen her only the night before... She hadn't changed -- she was still the same -- still completely devoted to me... and she told me we were going to see each other again and, never again, leave each other... She has promised me. Did you see her?
Yes, sire?
I have just had the most vivid... dream... about Josephine.
Bertrand, sire.
Who is there?

I suppose I might blame her for opening her house to the men most responsible to my downfall, but how can I?  She was on her own again, she had to look after her own affairs, and how can one blame her for having her head turned by the attention of Kings?
I have never heard an unkind word about her spoken.

Ah, my poor Josephine.  She was the most alluring, most glamorous creature I have ever known -- a woman in every sense of the word, and she had the kindest heart in the world.  She may have been a liar and a spendthrift, but she had something that was irresistible -- she was a women to her very fingertips... How impossible it is to believe that she is dead.
That is incredible.

She should have had Larrey or Corvisart.  They might have saved her... But why didn't anyone even write to me?  Can you believe that no one even bothered to write to me? Would you have believed that I should read such news in a newspaper?  How incredible!
I don't know, sire -- she had the Tsar's personal physician.
But did she have the best doctors? Wasn't there any chance at all to save her?
It is a terrible shock.
Josephine dead -- how unbelievable! How impossible it is to believe it. She was always physically so strong -- she was never ill a day in her life.
Let me see it.
This dispatch has just arrived from Aboukir, marked highest priority, for General Bonaparte's eyes only.
Come in.
Excuse me, General Bonaparte, but I believe this is an extremely urgent matter, requiring your immediate attention.
Come back in an hour.
General Bonaparte?
Oh, shit, that's not right.

To Joseph Bonaparte -- Dear Joseph, I have been informed by my wife of the cold and spiteful treatment she has been receiving at the hands of my family, since my departure.  I am also informed that you have refused to pay over to her any of the money I left with you expressly for this purpose.  Must you, too, take this opportunity during my absence to indulge the petty jealousies of the Bonaparte family?
Read it back.
You may go, Captain Charles.
Thank you, sir.  I will do that.

You will return to Paris tomorrow and you will carry my compliments and thanks to General Le Clerc for assigning such an excellent officer to carry out a responsibility which has meant so much to myself and to Madame Bonaparte.
Thank you, sir.
Then, you have my thanks, Captain Charles, for safely escorting Madame Bonaparte to Milan, and you may consider your assignment completed.
No, sir, none at all.
Did any difficulties of any kind arise during the trip?
Yes, sir.
Was the trip normal in every respect?
Yes, sir.
Was it he who assigned you to command the escort which accompanied Madame Bonaparte's coach?
Yes, sir, I am.
Captain Charles, I believe you are one of General Le Clerc's aides-de- camp.
Yes, sir, I had the honor of meeting them on the trip from Paris.
I believe you are acquainted with my brother, Joseph Bonaparte, and my aide, Major Junot.
I see...

Just a minute, General.  Listen, don't let them fool you with all their grand la-de-da.  They've all made their money from the war -- mostly from crooked war contracts. They say Citizen Barras has put away millions.
I thought not.  I noticed you by yourself, all night.
Ah-hh, no.
You don't know many of Citizen Barras' friends, do you?
Yes, as a matter of fact, it is.
That's a nice city.  This is your first time here, isn't it?
No, they're living in Nice now.
I haven't been back for ten years. Is your family still there?
I haven't been there for three years.
Have you been back recently?
Ajaccio.
Bastia -- and you?
Oh -- where do you come from?
I thought so, I noticed your name when you were announced.  I'm Corsican too -- my name is Arena.
Yes, I am.
Yes, sir.  I hope you will excuse me for asking, General Bonaparte, but are you Corsican?
A glass of champagne, please.
Yes, sir?
My God -- don't you recognize Mouton -- our regimental dog?  I would rather eat Cossack.
When you eat him, may I have some?
His paws are frozen and he cannot walk.
Why are you carrying the dog?
Ah, Didier -- you are alive.
Hello there, Picart.
My God -- this could be very bad for us... very bad, indeed.
From what we can tell, there are hundreds of agents, all over the city.  The combustibles seem to have been carefully placed beforehand, and all the fire-engines have been removed from the city.
But to start a fire like this in five hours -- how is it possible? It would take a carefully organized plan, tons of combustibles and hundreds of people.
We have already captured a dozen incendiaries, convicts, released just two days ago.  They said they were acting under orders of the secret police.
Impossible, I don't believe it.
Our troops have no part in this.  It has been started by the Russians!
I told Mortier that he would answer with his life for any looting.
It is the work of incendiaries.
How did it spread so quickly?
At first, it hardly seemed more than a routine fire.
Why didn't you wake me then?
The first reports came in at about ten.
When did it start?
My God, what a fire!
Four o'clock.
My God...!  What time is it?

May I suggest that we can prepare and sign the agreement, between ourselves, subject to the approval of the two Emperors.  Believe me, my dear friend, your Archduchess, Marie-Louis, may very well hold, in her hands, the future of our two countries.
But, my dear Duroc, how can I act without guidance from Vienna?  I haven't the slightest idea of how the Emperor Francis might feel about this.
No one can say how the Emperor's thoughts work, Ambassador, and unless we move quickly, he might change his mind again.
But this is not a matter which can be settled tonight, surely?

Earlier this afternoon, the Emperor refused the hand of the Grand Duchess Anna, of Russia, and, as I'm sure you can appreciate, he is quite able to change his mind again.  For the Emperor, to choose a wife, is only a matter of minutes.
What is that?
The Emperor has decided to marry your Archduchess, Marie-Louise.
Oh?
I beg your indulgence, Ambassador, but it is.
Yes, I have, and I hope you will forgive me, Duroc, but unless your visit is extremely urgent, I shall have to ask you to excuse me until tomorrow.
Indeed you have, Ambassador.  Have you sent for a doctor?
Ah, good evening, my dear Duroc. I'm afraid I've been out hunting and I have had a rather bad fall.
Good heavens, Ambassador -- what has happened?
You realize, of course, that thousands of swords have been collected.  How do you expect me to find yours?
My father's sword means more to me than any other possession I have.
Well, then, you have a lot of initiative, my young friend.
No, sir.
Does your mother know you have come?
He said no one had the authority to rescind the order except you.
And he sent you to me?
I told the Lieutenant my late father was General Alexander de Beauharnais, and asked if there was any consideration that might be given to his memory.
A sword is a weapon whatever else you might wish to use it for.

This morning, a Lieutenant and three soldiers came to our house and asked if we had weapons.  I explained we had only my late father's sword, which, in fact, was not a weapon but only a keepsake of memory.
That is correct.
I believe you issued an order that all citizens of Paris must hand over any weapons that they have in their possession.
I have met her.  What is your business with me?
Yes, sir.  Are you acquainted with her?
I am, Citizen.  Is your mother Madame Josephine de Beauharnais?
Good morning, sir.  Are you General Bonaparte?
Good morning, Citizen de Beauharnais.
Ah, well, that is the first rule of warfare.  You must wear long-sleeved and long-legged underwear.  You can never conjure up brilliancies with a cold bottom.
No -- not as a rule.
Francis, may I ask whether you wear warm winter underwear?
Thank you, Napoleon.
I'll have the fire built up.
Thank you.
Would you like some brandy?
I'm afraid I am, just a bit.
My dear Francis, you do seem extremely uncomfortable.
But he asked me to say...  on his behalf... that your achievements have increased his...  admiration for you, and that he believes... your success is predestined by heaven...  and that his army...
I see.
I'm afraid he has been rather upset by the outcome of the battle.
I very much doubt that he will.

Yes -- an excellent idea.
Shall we move closer to the fire?

I fear our meeting is long overdue... Napoleon.
Ah, my dear Francis, what a genuine pleasure it is to meet you at last.
Oh, yes... of course.
Please, sir, come into bed or I shall die of a chill.
That's a very nice name.  Where are you from?
Lisette La Croix.

Lisette.
What's your name?
Oh, I'm sorry about that.
Br-rrr, these sheets are like ice.

Uh-hh... yes, of course -- if you would like to go... there... but... I have very little money.
Would you like to take me there, so that we can get warm, sir?
Well, it must be a good deal warmer than it is here on the street.
Is it a nice warm room, sir?
No... I have a... room... at the Hotel de Perrin.
Are you staying with a friend, sir?
No, I'm only here on leave.  My regiment is at Valence.
One must take life as it comes -- do you live in Lyon, sir?
Oh, I see... That must be a great burden.
Well, one must do something to live, you know -- and I have an elderly mother who depends on me.
Then what brings you out on such a night?
Yes, I am, sir.
You must be chilled to the bone, standing out of doors like this.
Yes, it must be.
Yes, it is.  It must be one of the worst nights we have had this winter.
The weather is terrible, isn't it, sir?
Good evening, Mademoiselle.
Good evening, sir.
Only as a last resort.  What are the Councils doing now?
Will you use the troops?
My dear Joseph, the only thing that is clear is that my wife is a slut -- and while a man may want a slut for his mistress, he does not want her for his wife.
She will probably appear with a dozen excuses and you will forgive her anyway.

When is she supposed to return?
Well, you shall see.
Of course not, but such violence of feeling makes me wonder.

But you can do the same thing in six months.  The next few weeks may be the most important ones in your life.
It is time to clarify the situation. Everything is over between us.
You must not act impetuously.

You can't be serious.  It would not be good to become another husband out of a Moliere farce.
I know of no better time.
You know I am only too happy to be of help to you, but surely this isn't the ideal moment to involve yourself in such matters.
The important thing is to find the right lawyer.  One who will not protract the thing indefinitely, in the courts.
And you, Junot?

You would tell me, Joseph, wouldn't you?

Not even the slightest hint of something?

Junot?
No...
Naturally, one does not take much stock in such a piece of filth but, on the other hand, it is not the sort of thing one can simply ignore. What do you think, Joseph?

To Citizen General Bonaparte from one who does not wish to see him dishonored by his wife.  You should know, Citizen General, that your wife has taken a lover, one Captain Hippolyte Charles... undated and unsigned.
I would like both of you to read this.  Please read it aloud.

Oh -- I didn't tell you... I've seen Dr. Corvisart, and he was very reassuring and encouraging. Do you expect me to believe that?
Now, I know that I shall die if you leave me.
And now?
I thought I was.  I was confused.
Were you in love with him?

Oh, you must forgive me, General Bonaparte, I'm afraid you will think me incredibly stupid but I know absolutely nothing about this. Oh... how very nice of you to bring that for Eugene... Did General de Beauharnais give it to you?

He will stand by his agreement -- I know him better than you do.

I hope that understanding is worth as much as you think it is, sire. My impression of Alexander is that he is moody and impressionable, capable of acting on sudden impulses which then lead to sudden embarrassments.  He is an unpredictable mixture of idealism and vanity.  You have dazzled him, and you have performed a diplomatic miracle, but Alexander is weak and he is easily influenced by the last one who has his ear.
Alexander and I are friends.  We have reached an understanding.
And where do you place Alexander?
What you are talking about is a gamble on moderation -- when I gamble, I prefer to gamble on force.
What I am talking about is moderation.

My dear Talleyrand, none of the Kings of Europe bear any friendship for France.  It is easy for you to talk of reliable treaties.  The only treaties you have been able to negotiate are the ones I have won on the battlefield.
Not one I should like to rely on. Francis is still smarting under the terms he had to accept after Austerlitz, and he is under great pressure to recover his losses.
We have a treaty with Austria.
England can make no move against you on the Continent without Austria.  A reliable treaty with Austria would end her hopes in that regard.

I very seriously doubt it.  I don't think there is any possibility of making peace with England so long as she sees herself safe from invasion. That is why we must increase the pressure on her economy.  With Russia in the Continental Blockade, England must collapse.  More than 40% of her trade is with the Continent and Russia.
Do you think Alexander has any chance to succeed as a mediator?
That is correct.

Now, the section headed "Secret Clauses of the Treaty" -- Article 14b, provides for Alexander to serve as mediator between France and England and, if he fails to achieve a preliminary agreement within four months, it further provides that Russia is to go to war against England, and close her ports to English trade.
Yes, he has.
Has Alexander agreed to this?
I did not ask her to go to war against me.
Those are extremely harsh terms.

Article 46, calls for the virtual dismemberment of Prussia, reducing her population by half and her army to a token force.
Monsieur Varlac, I will count slowly to five, and if you have not begun to get down from the cart by then, I will carry out your execution, on the spot.
I suggest that you leave with your men while you can.
Monsieur Varlac, do not pretend to speak for these good people whom you have misled and inflamed with violent speech.  Now, I order you to come down from the cart.
Citizen Lieutenant, my advice is to leave this town at once with your men.  We do not wish to do harm to our brothers in uniform.
No, Monsieur Varlac, my warrant is only for you.  Now, will you please come down at once.  You will be taken back to Chalon for trial.
Then do you propose to arrest all of us, Citizen Lieutenant?  For I was not there alone.

You may save your philosophy for the magistrate, Monsieur Varlac.  I am only a simple officer in the army, and to me what you have done is called murder, and his always been called murder by honest men.

A year ago, the whole of Europe was marching alongside of us.  Today, the whole of Europe is marching against us.

On January 1st, 1814, France itself was invaded.  Now, with a small army of raw recruits, Napoleon would have to face the powerful combination of England, Russia, Prussia and Austria, operating against him together, for the first time.  The balance of numbers had tilted irretrievably against him.

With his army of 400,000 men in concealed bivouacs, on a ten mile front, in the forests, bordering the banks of the Vistula river, Napoleon conducted a last minute personal reconnaissance, disguised in the uniform of a Polish lancer.
I know Alexander.  His imagination must be struck by some great, bold, powerful stroke, and he will come back to me, just as he did at Friedland.
If the French army had been commanded at Jena and Auerstadt by a tailor, the King of Prussia would certainly have gained the day.

Led by the warlike Queen Louisa, and her fashion-minded husband, King Frederich Wilhelm, the Prussians still believed themselves cast in the mold of Frederick the Great, and more than a match for Napoleon. Duroc, I have a bill here for 600,000 francs from Tirot, for building the Imperial throne and six decorated arm-chairs.  The amount is absurd -- and, at least twice too much.
On December 2, 1804, Napoleon was made Emperor of France.  He would later say:  "I found the crown lying in the gutter and I picked it up."
From that moment on, I foresaw what I might be.  Already I felt the earth flee beneath me, as if I were being carried away up to the sky.

Napoleon would soon arouse the resentment of the Directory in Paris, exceeding his authority, making political decisions and treaties like a Roman Conqueror, enlarging his role to ruler of Italy.  Only his tremendous success and ever increasing popularity prevented the Directory from replacing him.
It will scarcely be considered credible, perhaps, but our whole business consisted in eating cherries together.

His moods at this time were complex and varied.
My mother has always loved me.  She would do anything for me.

Napoleon was born at Ajaccio in Corsica on August 15th, 1769.  He had not been a healthy baby and his mother, Letizia, lavished him with care and devotion.  In middle age, he would write about her from St. Helena.

Oh, yes, Grandmama - I wait until I hear...
Don't you, child?
No, no child... shush... it's all right ...
No, it wasn't a bat! I saw this horrible man - I remember him, I think...
Anastasia! It was just a bat! It's gone, dear...
Don't worry about that now, child, it will all come back to you now that you're home...
... and that Christmas dinner, when Cook made that awful plum pudding and we hid it in our pockets so we wouldn't hurt her feelings! I do remember so much now, Grandmama, - but not everything.
THINGS MY HEAR USED TO KNOW THINGS IT YEARS TO REMEMBER
PAR AWAY, LONG AGO GLOWING DEEP AS AN EMBER
I remember something lost ... I'm so confused! Oh, please, just tell me if you recognize me! Do you think I could have... belonged to you ...
Do you remember this?
I don't know! I don't want to hurt you...
Who are you, child?
Shut up!
PARSE HOLDS THE KEY TO MY HEART FRENCH- BAT- CHICKS HANG OUT AT MONTMARTRE WE'LL EAT SOME IN-SECTS THEN GO BACK AND HAVE --
Me? No. Rich food - it kills me. Ever try and fly after one of those heavy sauces?
Bartok ... have you ever been to Paris?
She leads a charmed life, that little one ... Someone is always there to save her. In the palace as a child, on the train and now ... it's him.
Boy, don't you hate it when that happens?
What do you think is the most humiliating way to die?
I'm getting pneumonia. I have a fever. Feel my forehead...
Bartok... a question.
I'm getting a chest cold..
Oy... not a road trip. I get wagon sick, you know that.
Yesss... our power is much stronger when were near. We must get close to her.
Evil, powerful beings - I have their power only if I contain them, control them. If they should all be released at once... well ...
You'd lose your security deposit?
Do you have any idea what would happen if that broke?!

My Aunt Bella, sweet woman not the brightest bat in the world - she used to hang right side up, anyway she always said "Curses were made to be broken". Course, she said it in those irritating little bat squeaks, so it wasn't quite so profound...
I cursed then all!
Hey, she's just a kid. And she's going to Paris outta sight, outta mind, outta Russia.
How do you know?
Trust me, it's her!
Okay... you're not gonna like this but, well, it looks like Anastasia is ... still alive.
Get to the point sometime tonight.. I'm late for a wenching.

So, I'm cruisin' the rafters and... what can I say, I struck out. I thought chicks would like the fact that I can talk, you know but, I mean, the way things are going I couldn't get invited to a plague.  Someone's gotta clean that up...
Why would I ever be angry with you, little friend?
No, I really like my tongue... we're very attached.  Oyyyy... Okay, now... promise you won't get angry.
I gave you that tongue and I can rip it out!
And what do you want, my little rat-with-wings?
Oh my God!  Don't do that ... feel my heart. Go ahead. I'm dying here ...
What?
She found her home. Maybe it's time I found one too!
So where will you go?
Watch me.
But this invitation came from the Empress herself! It's the social event of the decade! You can't turn it down!
Dmitri ... You must understand that once you take her to Tatiana... well, it's over... nothing can happen between you. She's a princess and you're a commoner.
What do you mean?
Life is funny, isn't it. You find the right girl ... and then you lose her.
Are you feeling all right?
We did it! We did it, my boy! We're going to see Tatiana at the ballet tonight and we're going to be rich! Rich!
It worked in Odessa...
The "Odessa Dunk"?
If I used the word "bleak" I would be optimistic.
How is our current financial status?
Ah! Let us begin!
See? The Princess is under there ...
Pray he's color-blind...
What do we do now?
Yes. And I hate that in a woman.
Well, she certainly has a mind of her own.
Royalty do not help people with their luggage.
You're a princess...
What a world - a man who was in my position in society is calling a peasant 'Your Highness".
Wake up, your highness - we should start getting used to saying it.
Wake up, young lady, that's our train.
Would you have leaned over Rembrant's shoulder and told him to paint faster?
Hurry up with those papers.
Ew. . .  the honest type.
She doesn't want to do anything "dishonest". . .
Look!
He's her?
It's her.
That was your dinner!  I do hope there is no cabbage in Paris!
What was that?
We will.  We <u>have</u> to.  Come on, Vlad - she's out there.
It's no use, Dmitri - we'll never find the right girl!
Run, Anya -  go...
I'll show you!
STOP IT! I DID SO KILL THEM! And I'm going to kill Anastasia.
You're insane! You didn't kill the Romonovs - it was the...
The same thing I wanted ten years ago - all the Romonovs dead I got the others, now I have to finish up with that nuisance, Anastasia...
What do you want?!

I know, I know ... you thought I was dead. That's how the history books will remember me - not as the ruler of all of Russia, which I SHOULD HAVE BEEN - but as the guy who was never dead when you expected him to be.
Rasputin!
So. You don't want to go to the coronation, eh?
Oh, Dmitri.I wish that I could.
And tell me that she's happy.
She does.
Promise me she'll have her home.
That last night in the palace... one boy showed us kindness and courage. You were the boy who saved our lives, weren't you?  Please, is there nothing I can do to repay you?
I should go
You are the boy ...
Empress, no! I will not take the money! I just came to tell you I was sorry...
I want you to have the reward money - you've earned it.
No. Empress, you --
I sent for you because I owe you a debt of gratitude larger than I can ever repay
What I <U>found</U>your was your granddaughter!
Anastasia's music box... She had this all these years...  You could have found it...
You! How dare you?! Stop this car immediately!
I'm not Ulo and I won't slow down. But you will listen to me!
Remove him at once.
Please, if you'd just listen...
How much pain will you inflict on an old woman for money?!
I need to speak with the Dowager Empress ...
After all I've done for your family - YOU TRIED TO KILL MEEEEEE ! ! !
I did no such thing!
You gave the orders!
I had nothing to do with it!
Despite being shot, poisoned and thrown into an icy river . . . YES!
Rasputin!  You're alive . . .
Oh, heavens, no... but ...  She is going to be at the Ballet Russe tonight! That's the Russian Ballet - Russe for Russian, oh those crazy French... they only go to see which dancers will defect.
Perhaps you could convince her?
Oh, heavens I must say... no, no actually, I can't - Tatiana has refused to see any more girls.
Then, you'll take her to see Tatiana?
Oh, heavens - I must say, yes.
Are you impressed with our Anastasia?
Oh good! We haven't seen an Anastasia in several days!
May I present her Royal Highness Princess Anastasia!
Who cares, Z.  All I know is, we gotta dig.  We're not the ones in charge.
This colony needs another tunnel like a hole in the ground.  Why are we even digging this thing?
Break's over.
Thank goodness.  Breaktime.

No, Z.  The squeaky wheel gets <u>thrown</u> <u>away</u>, alright?  You're a good ant, Z, even though you are a pain in my rear- segment.  I don't wanna see anything happen to you.  So quit mouthing off, before you get in trouble.
The squeaky wheel gets the oil.
Z, old pal...  SHUT UP!!!  It's bad enough there's a food shortage without you complaining about it every day.

Sorry Azteca.  Here you go, fellas! Fresh dirt!  Alley oop!  Shouldn't we be wearing gloves?  I mean this dirt is very...dirty. Doesn't anyone think of hygiene?  Boy am I hungry.  I'm so hungry I'm seeing double.  It looks like there's <u>two</u> million ants in here.  When's lunch?  Tomorrow, or the day after?
Right...because every ant's important!
Someone who follows his heart!
No -- an <u>individual</u>!
Invisible!
Well, because he's more than a worker...he's a...what did he call it, Azteca...
That's right!  He slaughtered hundreds of termites single-handedly!
You know, you're not just workers -- you can be whatever you want to be! Look at Z!  He started as a worker -- then he became a soldier!
Z?  <u>Our</u> Z?  The little guy made it!
Wait a minute, that's no soldier -- that's Z!
I'll make myself available...Listen, better watch out with the backtalk.  I don't know want you to end up like the guy who used to work next to me.  I'm afraid he got... <u>downsized</u>.
No -- I mean yes -- I mean -- if you don't have other plans.
Are you asking me out to dinner?
Sorry I got you in trouble.  But listen, you can share my rations.
I don't know what came over me, talking back like that.  I must be going crazy...
Mmm, yes, I see what you mean...
Nobody told me digging was so much fun!  You pick up the dirt, you move it, you pick it up again, you move it again -- lots of repetitions, you exercise the forceps, and the pincers --
Tell me about it.
I'm new...I was born yesterday.
Hey, slow it down, big boy.  You're making the rest of us look bad...How come I haven't seen you around here before?

Because...because he's <u>twice</u> the ant that you are.  I could <u>never</u> go through with marrying you.  I'm -- I'm an <u>individual</u>, and when I get married, it'll be to someone <u>I</u> choose.
You miss him?  <u>Why</u>?
Well you'll never be able to hurt him where he is now.  I miss him already.
It's a shame he died prematurely...I was hoping to kill him myself.
He's...he's dead.  You don't have to look for him anymore.  He was eaten by a praying mantis.
Oh...and I was afraid we had nothing in common...
Well...  I declared war!
So, um...how was your day?  What did you do?
Very well.  Carpenter, is there a convenient time to talk vis-a-vis: relationship?
General -- we have to talk sometime!
A <u>few</u>?
I mean, I've got the whole package, right?  A great life, a beautiful wife, and a few kids.

I know it's crazy, but -- I can't just leave.  Don't argue with me.  If I've learned anything, it's that the problems of two people don't add up to a hill of ants in this world.  Or beans.  Something like that.  Anyway, I've <u>got to warn the others</u>.
Z!  what are you doing?
Oh no...
Bala, that -- that lake we found -- I think the tunnel's right underneath it!  -- Formica's going to <u>flood the</u> <u>colony</u>!!!  That's what he meant when said there were too many ants!
There's something going on, Z --
Why do they have you tied up here?
Well, I...I know it's a little strange, but...I thought it might come in handy if I...needed a scarf someday.  Well, to be honest, I just liked having it.
You held onto this all that time?
Sorry, it's been through a war, not to mention everything else...
Well, "trouble" is my middle name. Actually, my  middle name is .985, but I don't tell people.  Hey, Bala, I...I actually have something of yours...you left it at the bar that night.
Just looking for fun, adventure, trouble, I guess.
So...you never did tell me...what made you come out to the worker bar that night?
Forget it.  You go ahead, I give up. I...I don't know what I was thinking. "Insectopia".
Come on, Z.
<u>This is all your fault</u>!!!
Yes?
Z...if we don't make it...I just want you to know....
Let's dig in!
You were right...you were right!  Z, it's <u>beautiful</u>!
We've found it!  <u>Insectopia</u>!  Look at all this food'
What difference does it make...we're both going to starve to death, or get squished, or set on fire...
Come on...tell me there wasn't just a little...something between us that first night at the bar.  The night we danced.
Face it, Z, we're lost!  We must have walked halfway across the world by now!  How did I get into this mess...
Well...I <u>am</u> the oldest.
So what makes you so special?
Well...no, but --
And only you can become a Queen?
Five thousand three hundred and ninety -- no.  About five thousand four hundred by now.
Look.  How many other Princesses are there?
General Formica won't let me die out here.  I'm his fiancee.
Princess, has it ever occurred to you that they're <u>not going to rescue you</u>?
Stop fooling around in there.
Hlllllllp!
Out here I'm just what?
Listen, "Princess", you can't order me around.  Out here, you're not the boss anymore -- out here, you're just --
Cut me down a soft leaf so I can take a nap.
This lake is huge!  And so close to the colony!  Think of the vacation potential!
Wait, I hear something!
Want a list?
Why didn't I listen to my mother ...why'd I have to go looking for trouble? Any ant would have given their left legs to be in my position...what's <u>wrong</u> with me?
Come on -- it's gone!  What are the chances of that happening again?
We're going to die!
<u>I</u> ruined <u>your</u> life?  Look, I was perfectly happy until I met you -- alright, I was miserable, but I was <u>happily miserable</u>.
My skin's dry, my exoskeleton is cracking...I wish I'd never met you, you ruined my life.
Water...water -- oh, you already said that.
Water...water...
That's not a name!  That's just a letter!
I've got a <u>name</u>.  It's <u>Z</u>.
Worker!  Come back here now!
Yeah, well I have it on a reliable source...  that it exists.  Now you follow the yellow egg...  <u>That</u> direction.
<u>Insectopia</u>?  You stupid worker, that's just a fairy tale!
Well, that's an appealing offer, but...considering the options...  You go back.  Me, I'm going to Insectopia.
Now, worker, you shall take me back to the colony, and have your head cut off and stuck on a sharp pole!
I <u>didn't</u> choose him.  What kind  of <u>idiot</u> would...  ...<u>choose</u> who she wanted to marry?
Is that the same standard you used to choose General Formica?
I was <u>slumming it</u>!  I danced with you because you were the most pathetic specimen in the place!
Oh come on, <u>you're</u> the one who came after me -- the swarthy, earthy, sensual worker!
Ha!  Don't make me laugh.  You're crazy about me!  That's why you lied and cheated to get near me!
Well I guess that makes us even.
I -- <u>hate</u> -- you.
Look around, sweetheart.
No!  There's no such thing as "just two ants."  You never see just two ants -- you see a million ants!
But can there be a society composed of just two ants?
Of course!  It defines society!  To deny the precept is to say that order is an arbitrary distinction applied by the society itself!
Theoretically, yes.  But is the monarchical hierarchy applicable without the underlying social structure to support it?
How dare you speak to me like that? I'm the Princess!
Who's the bigger idiot -- the idiot who gets kidnapped, or the idiot who lets herself get kidnapped by the idiot?
I've been kidnapped by the village idiot.
Climb up that tree and get a better view!
Excuse me, I --  Pardon me --  And they call them social insects.
Alright, alright, I'll try to get directions from one of the locals.
I order you to find out where we are!
How should <u>I know</u>?
What <u>was</u> that thing?
SSHH!!!  SSHH!!!
-- At the <u>worker bar</u>!  You were pretty hot to trot then!
Quiet -- sshhh!!
That's not what you said the <u>other</u> <u>night</u> --
I CAN'T DANCE WITH A WORKER!
Gee, uh, could you say it a little louder, I think there are some ants in the next colony who didn't hear you.
OH MY GOD, IT'S YOU!  YOU'RE A WORKER!!!  A filthy, stupid, disgusting WORKER!
No...as a matter of fact...
He was a worker.  I danced with him at a <u>worker's bar</u> just the other day. I'm not shocking you, am I?
No weirdly...You remind me of someone...
Divinely?
You dance...
Uh, sorry, General, I...I've always had this animal magnetism, it --
No, General.  I'm dancing with the war hero.
Oh...oh well then, one more won't matter.
Yes.
Ah, yes.  Well, charmed, I'm sure.  So, Princess, have you ever danced with a hero?
I'm Princess Bala.
And you are...?
Well, if single-handedly vanquishing the enemy and slaughtering a whole nestful of termites makes someone a hero, yes I am.
You're the hero of the recent termite campaign, aren't you?
Let me think.  Hmmnn...  Never.  Bye!
Wait!  When can I see you again?
Uh oh.  Goodbye!  Gotta run!
Aren't you gonna stand up for yourself?
Oh, that's okay, I'll let him off this time.  Are you crazy?  This guy's built like a pebble!  You know they do great prosthetic antennas nowadays --
You watch yours, soldier, or my worker friend will beat you up!
Why can't I just do whatever I want to do?  Why can't I just go wild?! Yahoo!
You -- you think I'm right?
You're right!
Why should everyone dance the same way?  It's as exciting as watching fungus grow.
Really?
Well, actually, uh -- I'm sort of making it up --
Are you sure this is a real dance?
<u>What</u>?
The palace, hunh?  I bet those royals really live it up.  Of course they're all a little, you know, from inbreeding --
I work in the palace, I don't get out much.
So uh -- how come I haven't seen you around here before?
Wanna dance?
What a bunch of losers.  Mindless zombies capitulating to an oppressive system --
Then if I go to the worker bar, it isn't improper.  Anyway, don't worry. No one will recognize us in our disguises.
Of course not --
And do Princesses do improper things?
Of course --
I'm the Princess, aren't I?
We shouldn't be doing this -- it isn't proper!
The worker bar!  Yes!  That's where I want to go!
There isn't anyplace else --  Except the worker bar.
The Club's so <u>stuffy</u>.  I want to try someplace different.
Mom!
Bala!
Darling, you must encourage the troops -- wave!
Who is that idiot?
Yes...he's wonderful...

Yes -- but I did my duty and sorted out all those messy feelings.  The wonderful thing about ant life is that everything is arranged.  Even marriage.  You're lucky -- General Formica is a paragon of anthood.
You did?
I felt the same way before I got married.  Confused.  Scared.
It's just that -- well, I'm honored that you selected me, and everything, I just thought the marriage might go a little more smoothly if -- we had a conversation?
Bala has always been a hopeless romantic, General.
Don't make my mistake, kid... don't...be a grunt...your whole life...
Barbatus, hang on -- Barbatus!!
I wonder...what...was it all...for...
Hang in there, buddy!  You can make it!  Just -- take deep breaths, I'll try and find your body -- it's gotta be around here somewhere!
No -- I can see it in your eyes.  I'm a goner.  It's alright, Z.  In this ant's army, a soldier's life ain't worth a sack of fungus.  I can't feel my legs...
No, no, you're...lookin' good. You've got good color in your cheeks.
Be honest, kid -- am I hurt bad?
Barbatus!
Barbatus?
Z!  Over here!
Don't get all sappy about it!
BARBATUS!  You -- you saved my life!
Maybe they went out for the evening. Let's leave them a message and head home.
Don't be scared, kid.  Barbatus's got yer back.
Superior numbers, kid!
So we're going back for more armor, right?  I mean, these guys are from outer space, how are we supposed to beat them?!
Our platoon has the best assignment of all.  We're the first into battle!
Well, what exactly does our platoon do?  Serve beverages?  Process paperwork?
Attack?  But -- I hate attacking! It's so hostile!
No -- we're going to attack the termites!
Yeah.  Well -- no.  She's kind of playing hard to get.  As a matter of fact, she's playing completely unattainable.  So, what's on the schedule?  A brisk walk?  a foraging expedition?
You just stick by old Barbatus. He'll watch out for you.  Whatsamatter, kid?  Leave a girl behind?
Trial membership?  Kid, when you join this ant's army, you're in for the full hitch.
I just joined up.  But I'm quitting! I got a trial membership!
You new, kid?
Uh, actually, we <u>are</u> outnumbered sir...
What are you doing?!  ATTACK!!  Come on, you yellow-bellies!  Don't just stand there, Carpenter! Make an example of yourself!
Ant Team Six...
Desperate times call for desperate measures.  Get me Ant Team Six.
Scattered reports, sir.  Rumors. Nothing reliable.
What do we have on this "Insectopia"?
No one should have to.  Have him brought to me.
Well, uh, who notices workers, sir?
Notice the big one, holding hands with the female?
I've never seen anything like it, General, they're they're...well, look!
Dammit, this tunnel is priority A-1! We can't afford <u>any delays</u> on this project!
Duty calls!
Fourteen-fifty hours, sir.
Outstanding.  Princess...?
Actually, sir, we're ahead of schedule.  We have thirty-six seconds available right now.
Princess!  You look -- outstanding. Is there anything I can do for you?
Princess Bala, sir.  Your fiancee.
No, sir!
Not that one.  Or that one.
That's correct, sir!
We know what makes an ant colony strong, don't we?  We know that no ant can be an individual.  No <u>single</u> ant matters, right?
Okay, son.
I...I have no idea, sir.
So tell me.  Where's Z?
Thank you, sir.
Good.  You're a good soldier.
Oh, no, sir!
Well now <u>you</u> haven't fallen for this silly idea of individuality, have you?
Yeah...I mean...well...I don't know, really, sir.
So this Z...he fancies himself an individual?
Can't we all settle this like adults -- we're not larvae anymore --
ARREST HIM!
Well it wasn't a masquerade, really, it was more what I'd call a clever ruse --
What's this?  A <u>worker</u> has been masquerading as a war hero?!
Oh, of course --
May I cut in?
Oh, hey, that's great, I think I see an old war buddy over there, it's been fun chatting.  Good luck with the hallucinations.

I tell you son, sometimes, at night, I see myself in battle, fighting a horrible, faceless enemy, with the future of our whole species at stake. And always, the dream ends with each of us plunging his sword into the other's heart...
Well I, I don't think "living it up" is the right term -- how about "working themselves to death"?
Negatory.  <u>Too many ants</u>.  And while we soldiers go out there, and fight, and bleed, and die for the colony, the namby-pamby workers live it up back home.
...Not enough food?
Yes, and do you know <u>why</u> there's a food shortage?
Wow, what a spread -- you know, there's a food shortage in the rest of the colony.
In love?  I'm just a plain old soldier at heart.  I'll tell you what I love -- the field -- blood -- death -- orders...and the company of other warriors.
So...you two are in love?
Affirmative.
Engaged?  As in you're getting married?
Well she better -- she's engaged to one.  <u>Me</u>!
Well, I generally just make belittling comments and snicker behind death's back.  So, tell me, fellow war-monger...do you think Princess Bala likes men in uniform?
Son, you're an ant after my own heart.  A warrior.  An ant that looks death right in the face and <u>laughs</u>.
ONE TO NOTHING!
Of course.  The entire royal family will be there to honor you.
Royal victory party?  Will...will Princess Bala be there?
Damn, I'm proud of you, boy.  I wish I had a hundred ants of your caliber. The world would tremble.  Now, time for some R and R.  You're invited to the royal victory party!
No -- you -- you don't understand!
Dammit, I'm proud to be an ant.  And I know each and every one of you boys will do your duty.  Dismissed.
Geez, and I forgot my toothbrush.

Now I've heard a lot of scuttlebutt about a <u>food shortage</u>.  Well you boys are gonna be taken care of.  But in the meantime we're gonna eat the enemy for <u>breakfast</u>, we are gonna eat the enemy for <u>lunch</u>, and we are gonna eat the enemy for <u>dinner</u>!
Lays it on a little thick, doesn't he?  If you ask me, he's one giant bore.
Alright, let's move out!
Very well, General -- I know you -- all work and no play!
'Fraid not, your majesty.  Goodbye, your majesty.
But General -- this tunnel is your baby!  You're sure you can't stay ?
Your majesty, I'm afraid matters of state keep me from attending the ceremony.
They should be...  But there's something funny about that soldier.
All these parties are so marvellously <u>alike</u>.
I'll take your suggestion under advisement, Princess.  In the meanwhile --
Look, General!  A darling baby soldier!  Don't try to be a hero!  Just make sure you come back in one piece!  Next!
Conversation...yes...well...  Wasn't she briefed?
Yes, General Formica.  Carry on, my good man!  I don't know what we would do without you.
I do not recollect, your majesty. Will that be all?
No snacking between meals!  Off you go!  Now -- what were we saying?

Please don't worry, your majesty. Leave the worrying to me.  As you know, I'm not an ant of half- measures.  I don't pussyfoot around. This crisis is my number one priority, and I promise you it's being dealt with swiftly, and decisively.
Yes, what else?
We are launching a major offensive to expand our foraging territory...

General, the severe food shortage that faces the colony...<u>pains</u> me. The thought of any of my children going hungry...  Who's the cutest widdle worker?  You are!  Yes, you!  Don't forget to brush your teeth!  Ship 'er out.  What steps are you taking to remedy the situation?
But -- but I've always felt life was about finding meaning...and then sharing it with someone special, someone you love.
You see?  Being an ant is being able to say, "Hey -- <u>I'm</u> meaningless, <u>you're</u> meaningless."
Right!  Ants!  Millions of creatures, each with his assigned task, all pulling together!
...Ants...
What do you see out there?
I'm glad you asked me that question!
Why are we so successful?
Ask me why we're so successful.
YES!!!  You know, people ask me, "Doctor, why are you always happy?" And I tell them it's mind over matter.  I don't <u>mind</u> that I don't <u>matter</u>!  Do you get it?  Do you get it?
...I should?
Terrific!  You <u>should</u> feel insignificant!

I feel...isolated.  Different.  I've got abandonment issues.  My father flew away when I was just a larva. My mother didn't have much time for me...when you have five million siblings, it's difficult to get attention.  I feel physically inadequate -- I've never been able to lift more than ten times my own weight.  Sometimes I think I'm just not cut out to be a worker.  But I don't have any other options.  I was assigned to trade school when I was just a <u>grub</u>.  The whole system just...makes me feel...<u>insignificant</u>.
You heard the ant -- DIG!!!
Yeah, but I hate drowning more!  Now <u>dig</u>!
Don't tell anyone you're a worker. Follow that column over there.  And come right back after the inspection!
What do I do?
Yeah, I know.
You're a real buddy.
Wear this.
Maybe I'll get lucky.  You know, Z, I wouldn't do this for anyone but you...
You bet!  They'll really go for a sensitive guy like you!
Will you introduce me to some worker girls?
Well I'm gonna <u>start</u> doing things for you...
I can't think of any.

What's gonna go wrong?!  I take your place for the royal inspection.  Bala comes strolling down the line, she sees me -- <u>bingo</u>!  Love is rekindled, and she takes me up to the palace for a little...  tea and crumpets... and you take your place again, and go march around to your heart's content!
It's a sign that you're crazy!  Do you know what the penalty for impersonating a soldier is?

Well, you just sit here and be a party-pooper.

We declared war again?  Are you scared?

Good. Professor Brown tested the tarp, noting in satisfaction that it was secure. I'll pick you up in front of the school at midnight. Don't be late -- we're cutting it close as it is. We've got a long drive ahead of us.

If they don't have a second date, they won't fall in love. If they don't fall in love, they won't get married, and if they don't get married, you'll never be born!

Curious... Very curious....

You forget -- time travel is instantaneous. The time machine would melt, but you would have already travelled through time. Of course, it's a moot point regardless. The only place atomic bombs are detonated is at the Army's Nevada Test Site, and those tests are kept absolutely top secret.

An atomic bomb.

Let me put it on a level you can understand. You don't belong here. You don't know anything about this world. Then I would have figured out to get back in through the events in the natural course of history! Don't you understand? The fabric of history is very delicate. Anything you do could have serious consequences!

The power converter...

No! Don't tell me!  I don't want to know the future! My knowledge of future events... your mere presence here... could have devastating effects on the course of history. And altering history is a responsibility that I do not wish to bear. My immediate response is to send you back to your own time.
You didn't, Professor. It was an accident! You see, what happened --
You've convinced me that you must be who you say you are. No living human has ever seen this machine.  But why? Why even in my twilight years would I remotely consider sending someone back in time?
Yeah, a shopping mall. You know, a shopping mall?
A mall?

Marty.

Don't you understand? The mere act of sending matter back in time would change the course of events, and changing history is a responsibility that I do not wish to bear.

Marty, that would alter history.

A gold mine?

Is Shemp all right?

shhh...

oh dear.
